The Republican contest is still led by brain surgeon Ben Carson, but voters who have made up their minds favour Trump by a factor of two to one.
Six out of ten Republicans say they agree with Trump on immigration.
Ever since Donald Trump called Mexican immigrants "rapists" at the kickoff of his campaign two months ago, immigration has been at the forefront of the 2016 conversation.
Some think Trump's talk has driven off important Hispanic voters and damaged his rebranding efforts.
But according to a new ABC/Post poll released on Monday, six out of ten Republicans say they agree with Trump on immigration issues.
So, as long as the issue of immigration stays on the agenda, Trump seems likely to stay on it too.

Donald Trump and Ben Carson, who have no political experience, are roughly splitting the Republican vote.

And they're angry with Washington.

A Des Moines Register/Bloomberg poll two weeks ago in Iowa showed that three out of every four Republicans in Iowa were angry with Republicans in Congress, with 54 percent "dissatisfied" and 21 percent "extremely angry."
Jeremy Corbyn is going to be at the lectern for the first time in Questions to the Prime Minister.
Ever since he was elected, his appearances at the Prime Minister's Questions have been much anticipated
For the first time after David Cameron, the leader of the new Labor Party Jeremy Corbyn will be on the podium of Questions to the Prime Minister.
Mr. Corbyn will be due to ask six questions later in the day, and his performance is being closely watched by the media and Labor MPs.
The weekly show made a call for "Less theater and more realness."
He also said he could skip certain sessions, leaving them to his colleagues.
This will be the first parliamentary test of his leadership since Mr Corbyn appointed his shadow cabinet and delivered a speech at the TUC annual congress on Tuesday.

Meanwhile, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn's silence during the national anthem at a commemoration last Tuesday to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain is also being criticized by some Tory MPs and is the focus of front page news stories in the newspapers.
Mr. Corbyn's decision not to sing the national anthem drew attention.
A spokesman for Mr Corbyn said he stood in "respectful silence" and appreciated the "heroism of the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain."

However, Owen Smith, who is a member of Mr Corbyn's shadow cabinet, told the BBC's Newsnight programme that he would advise the Labour leader to sing the anthem "independently" of his belief in abolishing the monarchy.

Roughly a dozen shadow cabinet members, refusing to serve in Mr. Corbyn's top team over differences in economics, defense, and foreign policy and less than one in six members of Parliament from his own party supported him as a leader.
BBC political correspondent Robin Brant says there are differences within the Labour party as well, "over things like Jeremy Corbyn's position on Europe, the welfare cap."
Mr Corbyn told the TUC conference Labour would bring in new measures to abolish the cap completely.

Hours later, the shadow work and pensions secretary, Mr Smith, said he was opposed to the government's plans to cut the upper limit for claiming benefits from £26,000 to £23,000, and that he was "very clear" on the subject.
Mr Corbyn will be the fifth Labour leader to face David Cameron across the dispatch box since he became leader of the Conservative Party.
The Labour Party leader pledged a different approach to politics and said he had consulted “people power” and received more than 30,000 recommendations.

Islington North MP Jeremy Corbyn said that the Prime Minister's Questions was very adversarial and rather than indulge in the "gotcha" of the quick-witted ripostes, he wanted to focus on issues such as poverty, inequality and the difficulties facing young people.
When Mr Corbyn is not there, for example when Mr Cameron is abroad, he said he would be represented by the shadow business secretary, Angela Eagle, in the weekly prime minister's questions.

He even suggested that his fellow colleagues might also have the chance to speak from this podium from time to time, and told the Speaker of the House of Commons, John Bercow, that he would be applying for this.

When Mr. Cameron became leader in 2005 he said that he wanted to move away from the "puppet theatre" style of politics that he was often associated with through the Prime Minister's Questions program, but a few years later he admitted that he had failed to do so.

Since first broadcasted in 1990, the Questions for the Prime Minister programme has been used as a touchstone for measuring the decision-making capabilities of leaders, the dominance in the House of Commons, and the position of MPs among themselves; in contrast, some critics say that this has been caricaturised and comprehensive reform is needed.

BBC News went to meet one of the first graduates of the project.

If we decide to broadcast your material on BBC programmes or on the internet, we will publish your name as you have provided it to us (unless you ask us not to do so), but we will never publish your email address.
You may also send your videos and photographs.
If you do not request otherwise, we will publish your name as you informed us.
Sterling is rising as pay growth in the United Kingdom accelerates
After data showed that wages in the United Kingdom are rising, the British pound gained sharply and the FTSE 100 index also rose on the back of a bid for SABMiller.
In the United Kingdom, excluding bonuses, earnings increased 2.9 percent between May and July, compared to the same period last year.
This rate, which has increased the fastest since 2009, is also seen as one of the indicators of the possible increase in interest rates.
Sterling gained more than one percent against the US dollar to $1.5505 and 0.84 percent against euro to 1.3730 euros.
The FTSE 100 index increased by 1.49% to 6,229.21.
The company that drew the most attention among those companies was SABMiller, which received a favorable acquisition offer from its rival AB InBev and recorded a 20% increase.
The offer would bring together the world's two biggest beer companies and unite well-known brands such as Budweiser, Stella Artois, Peroni and Grolsch.

Burberry shares rose 0.9% after positive profit news from rival luxury retailer Richemont.
Q: Atlantik Okyanusunun kuzeyindeki en kalabalık ülke dünyanın en büyük petrol üreticisi olma ünvanını kiminle paylaşıyor?
A: Which country shares the title of the world's largest oil producer with the most populous country north of the Atlantic Ocean?
Richemont's current sales figures show that sales have started again in China, which is one of the key markets for Burberry, in addition to exceeding expectations.
Shares in the mining giant Glencore rose 5% after it said it had raised $2.5bn from the sale of new shares to reduce its debts.
Mondi, the packaging and paper group, were among the biggest fallers, losing 4.3% in value, after Goldman Sachs cut its recommendation on the stock to sell.
Shares in JD Sports rose 3.1% after the firm reported an 83% rise in pre-tax profits to £46.6m in the six months to 1 August.
JD Sports chairman said higher wages could harm expansion
JD Sports Chairman Peter Cowgill said an increase in the minimum wage for UK workers could mean "more spending power in the pockets of potential consumers".
However, he said that this spending power cannot cover his own high employee costs at his own company.
He also added that the cost might affect JD Sports' expansion plans and this could mean less extra work.
Metcash launches public campaign to fight off Aldi invasion
Metcash is trying to protect its IGA stores in South Australia and Western Australia from an Aldi attack.
Market wholesaler Metcash has launched a public campaign to protect its retail stores in South Australia and Western Australia against a $700m Aldi invasion.

While Aldi is gearing up to open its first store next year from two distribution centres in South Australia and Western Australia, which will bring its number to 120, Metcash and IGA supermarkets are strengthening their relationships with their local food suppliers, and the IGA brand is being built up with events and marketing in mainstream and social media, such as the Adelaide Show.

IGA retailers and suppliers are also contributing, with brands such as Simmo, the Dunsborough-based ice-cream manufacturer which produces tastings at IGA stores, and store owners such as the South Australian football league who are offering discounted tickets to loyal customers.
Food, liquor and hardware wholesaler Metcash is expected to reveal more detail about its defense strategy on the annual investor strategy day on September 29.

The risk is great because South Australia and Western Australia represent nearly 30 percent of Metcash's IGA store footprint and produce higher margins than Metcash's IGA network in the eastern states.

South Australian and Western Australian store owners see the narrow-mindedness negatively and the IGA retailers in NSW, Victoria and Queensland are enjoying a much stronger market share than they did in the east states; 30% in SA and 24% in WA more.

However, analysts like Morgan Stanley believe that Aldi will grab about 5 percent of the market in the first 12 months after it opens its first stores in these two states, and that it will take sales away from the current players, but generally from independent retailers.
In a report published this week, Morgan Stanley analyst Tom Kierath forecast that IGA retailers would lose $360 million within a year and Metcash $250 million by the end of 2016.
The estimate is based on projections that Aldi will open 25 stores in GA next year and 30 in BA, with each market generating $500 million and $600 million in sales, respectively.
Mr. Kierath, the loss of food and grocery sales as well as Metcash's high fixed cost base, could result in an EBIT of around $13 million for Metcash, he said.
Despite a recent Roy Morgan survey showing that Metcash's IGA customers are the most loyal customers, the company is losing market share in the east states, particularly to Aldi and Coles.

According to Morgan Stanley, Metcash's grocery and supermarket sales will decline by 3.8 percent in 2016, 4.1 percent in 2017, and 2.1 percent in 2018, which will push the market share from the 2015 level of 14 percent to 10.3 percent in 2020.
Last week, Magellan Financial Group founder and lead fund manager, Hamish Douglass, told a business dinner in Melbourne that Metcash was "highly likely to be wiped out within 10 years."
Metcash declined to respond to Mr. Douglas' comments.
But it is understood that a Metcash board member made contact with Mr Douglass last week.

IGA's market share has fallen from 18% in 2010 to 14% and Metcash's earnings from supplying about 1200 IGA retailers have fallen by 43% since 2012, with a decline in sales and margins showing the business is under less leverage as the pressure builds.

But the wholesaler is fighting back, spending more than $150 million a year matching shelf prices on hundreds of products a week at Coles and Woolworths, helping IGA retailers refurbish their stores, adding faster-growing fresh food and launching a better own-label supermarket range.

Ian Morrice, CEO of Metcash, says the price matching and shop refitting programmes are starting to bear fruit and the wholesaler expects to return to underlying profit growth for the first time in four years in 2017.
Thanasi Kokkinakis, is supported by Tennis Australia chairman Steve Healy
Thanasi Kokkinakis deserves more praise than criticism for his behavior.
Tennis Australia president Steve Healy says Thanasi Kokkinakis was an innocent victim caught up in the storm surrounding his mate Nick Kyrgios and deserves more praise than criticism.

Kokkinakis, the younger member of the talented duo known as the "Special K's", found himself under the unforgiving spotlights after his compatriot Kyrgios humiliated Stan Wawrinka at the Montreal Masters.

In the demanding match played in Cincinnati in the afternoon, Kokkinakis and his opponent Ryan Harrison were separated twice by the referee, and Harrison made the following statement: "Wawrinka came to Kyrgios, so I had to go to that kid as well."
Kokkinakis, who was most recently spotted breaking his racket in frustration at the US Open, was staunchly defended by Healy.
The young player is currently in Glasgow competing for the second singles spot behind Bernard Tomic in Australia's Davis Cup semifinal against Great Britain, alongside Sam Groth.
Healy said, "What I'm feeling really enthusiastic about is the idea that Thanasi's getting drawn into the discussion."

He was broken his racquet when he lost the game against a Canadian teenager, Denis Shapovalov but he was not the first player to do so and I know that Thanasi well enough to know that he would be disappointed with himself for doing so.
But in truth in the US, Harrison had to endure very provocative conditions with the rest, and I believe he deserves a bucket full of praise for managing himself well.
He has a great team, great family around him, and I think it has been overplayed a little bit.

He may be 19, but he is extremely mature, and he works very hard and fits in with the team, there are no problems with the other players, he is treated with great respect in the locker room, he carries out difficult training, is very balanced and mature, and in my opinion he deserves to be judged by his own standards.

Healy also backed the decision to welcome back Kyrgios for a key partnership, saying from Friday that the right thing for everyone was to take it "match by match", but start supporting the Canberran to come back as a long term asset for the team.
"First and foremost, we want the team to focus on the game, not the controversy surrounding Kyrgios," Healy said.

And in my view, Nick, as Federer and Murray and others have said, Nick got up really fast, grew up in front of the public eye, and made some horrible mistakes and deserves all of the criticism that he's getting, but we're trying to support him, we're trying to help him understand the consequences of his actions, and sometimes when the spot lights aren't on, I think deeply about whether it's appropriate, whether it's right for the team and right for him.
European migrant crisis: Hungary declares state of emergency, closes borders and arrests migrants
Hungary declared a state of emergency on Tuesday to cut off the flow of migrants, sealing its southern border with a razor-wire fence and detaining people trying to enter the country illegally.
Chaos erupted at the border as hundreds of migrants piled up in a neutral zone, and Serbian officials reacted angrily.

The immigrants who came as they escaped from the violence in their own countries have set up tents on the side of the road, and they have settled into these tents as they wait for an indefinite period of time between the control points of the two countries.
But their anger was growing.
As a police helicopter flew overhead, migrants shouted "Open the border!" and hurled insults at the Hungarian riot police.
Some of them refused the water and food given to them as a protest.
The Serbian Foreign Minister has said that Hungary's decision to send back migrants is "unacceptable" as the migrant flow from Macedonia and Greece continues.
(Serbia) wants to be part of the solution, not part of the problem in this process.
Ivica Dacic told Pragda that he needs to meet with Brussels and other countries in the coming days.
The tension at the Hungarian-Serbian border came just one day after the 28-member bloc failed to agree on a common migrant policy at a meeting in Brussels.

Ministers agreed to share responsibility for some 40,000 refugees who have poured into Greece and Italy in recent days, with the prospect of taking in another 120,000, including some from Hungary, over the coming month or by the end of the year.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Austria on Tuesday called for an EU summit to discuss the continent's migrant crisis next week.
Hungary, however, is not expecting Brussels or its neighbors to take any concrete steps on the matter.

The emergency call issued on Tuesday by the two southern regions gave the authorities broad powers to face the crisis, including the ability to close roads if necessary and accelerate the trial of migrants.

On the other hand, Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said they planned to stretch barbed wire along their border with Romania as well in order to stop the migrant flow from this country after they put barbed wire along their border with Serbia.
CBS News reporter Charlie D'Agata announced that prisoners in jails are even being recruited to build the fences between Hungary and Serbia.

In the last few months, Hungary has become an important bottleneck and transit point for migrants to the European Union, and most of these migrants are refugees fleeing wars in Syria and other Middle Eastern countries.

Prime Minister Viktor Orban is insistent on the view that most migrants are "economic migrants" seeking a better life in Europe rather than innocent people fleeing war, which is a view completely contrary to other EU countries, including Germany.
The new midnight laws in Hungary which make climbing or damaging the four-meter-high barbed wire fence on the Serbia border a criminal offence also introduce stricter penalties for human traffickers.

At a press conference in the southern city of Szeged, Zoltan Kovacs, the government spokesman, said: "Due to the situation caused by the mass migration, the government of Hungary is declaring a state of emergency".
On one thing, we are absolutely clear: it is an offense to illegally cross the border.
Although the deployment of the forces still needs to be approved by parliament, Associated Press reporters in the region say they have seen armed, dog-equipped soldiers in the area in recent days.
Orban's domestic security adviser Gyorgy Bakondi said authorities caught 45 people trying to cross the border and 15 who had managed to enter the country.
They got past the barbed wire, now they are under police supervision and are accused of committing a crime under the new law.
Officials are quickly repairing the barbed wire.
Hungarian officials also closed two of the country's seven border crossings with Serbia on Tuesday morning, using a train carriage covered with barbed wire to close one of them.
The chaos spilled over to the main crossing point near Roszke when the Hungarians brought in a metal container with people packed in for processing.
Although 20 people were able to get inside, thousands remained outside.
Another group of migrants blocked the highway connecting Serbia and Hungary demanding Hungary to let them in, and they said they would not accept food and water supplies until then.
Election 2016: Hillary Clinton's edge over Bernie Sanders in the national polls has dwindled to a virtual tie
Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton continues to lead by double digits in the Democratic race for the presidential nomination, but Sen. Bernie Sanders is catching up.
Clinton is currently receiving 47% of Democratic votes (down 58%), while Sanders is in second place with 27% (up 17%).
Vice President Joe Biden, who is undecided about running for president, is polling at 15 percent of Democratic votes.
For months before the first primaries, most Democratic voters have said it is too soon to say which candidate they would support.
But Clinton supporters are more certain of their choices than supporters of the other candidates.
Since last month's CBS News Poll, Clinton has lost ground among a number of demographic groups, while Sanders has gained some.
Clinton leads big among women and moderates, but this gap is closing.
Support among men has fallen dramatically, and Sanders trails by just 5 points.
Clinton's advantage among Democratic voters younger than 50 has evaporated, and she and Sanders now find themselves in an equal position.
But Clinton is ahead by a large margin among older voters.
Last month, Clinton was leading Sanders by double digits amongst liberals, but now Sanders is five points ahead in this group.
About half of national Democratic voters say they would passionately support Clinton if she were the party's nominee.
One quarter would support him under some conditions, while a further 15 percent would only support him if he became the candidate.
A segment of six percent does not support Clinton.
Perhaps not surprisingly, Clinton's current supporters are particularly likely to back her passionately.
The views among those who don't currently support Clinton are even more mixed - just a quarter can muster passionate support for her.
While 48% of the Democrats say they will support Hillary Clinton passionately, they talk about the less Republican-leaning candidate Donald Trump (35%).

When asked open-ended questions about why Clinton supporters wanted Clinton to run, the top answers were that she has the right experience (16 percent), that it is time to elect a woman as president (13 percent), and that she is the best candidate for the job (10 percent).
Clinton's supporters also point to her relationship with Bill Clinton (9%).
Being conciliatory in problems and being electable are among the criteria listed.
As a vice president with potential to run for president, 57 percent of Democratic voters might like to see her in the race, but a third of them don’t think that way.
When asked who Democratic voters want as the party's second choice in the primaries, Biden is at the top.
Half of Clinton’s supporters say Biden would beat Sanders by a wide margin, according to Clinton.
If Biden does not enter the Democratic candidacy race, Hillary Clinton's advantage over Sanders increases; in a race with Biden, the level of 20 points increases to 30 points if Biden is not there.
Fifty-five percent of Democratic voters see Clinton as the candidate with the best chance of winning the general election; however, this figure has dropped from 78 percent last month.
Biden, by this measure, is a distant second, though the percentage of voters who see him as the most electable has grown.
When asked what the most important issue is in their choice of a candidate, Democratic voters prioritize the issues over electability.
As last month, no Democrat candidate or candidate seems not to be acceptable to the voters.
Democratic candidates or contenders are performing well with the primary electorate in some critical characteristics.
The majority see Clinton, Sanders and Biden as honest and trustworthy, as well as having strong leadership qualities.
Biden ranks first in terms of honesty, whereas Clinton is strong on leadership.
About 30 percent of Democratic voters say Clinton is not honest and trustworthy, while about half as many say the same about Sanders (15 percent), and 27 percent have no opinion on the question.
Democrat voters also generally see Clinton, Sanders and Biden as in line with their ideology.
By any measure, a quarter of Democratic voters have no opinion of Sanders.

As questions continue to surround her use of a personal email address and server while Secretary of State, most Democratic voters say they find the explanation satisfactory and say it doesn't affect their view of her.
But this is a different story in general American public.
While half of Americans are now dissatisfied with his explanations, only a third consider them satisfactory.
Public opinion on the issue was divided shortly after the problem was brought into focus in March.
While most Americans say the e-mail controversy has not changed their overall opinion of Clinton, that share has increased to 36% who have a negative opinion.
These are generally Republicans, and more than six in ten say their view of Clinton has been damaged.

While registered voters generally still see Clinton as honest and trustworthy, the issue continues to be a problem overall: Only 32% now see her that way, down eight points from last month and 15 points since May.
Sixty-two percent of registered voters do not find him honest and trustworthy.
At the same time, 55 percent of the registered voters in the whole country also do not consider Trump honest and reliable.
Meanwhile, both Clinton and Trump receive good grades on leadership.
Of the six contestants who took part in the test, Biden, Carson and Bush received the highest scores on honesty.
More than Sanders, most people find Carson to be honest, but like Carson, most people do not have an opinion about him either.
The margin of error on the samples of 351 Democratic electors is plus or minus 6 percent.
Ben Carson is in second in national polls behind Donald Trump.
According to the newest CBS News/New York Times poll, Ben Carson is running close on the heels of Donald Trump.
A new survey shows that the two candidates are each getting about half the vote, with the other candidates not having much of a chance.

National Republican voters continue to support Mr. Trump by large margins, with support rising from 23 percent in the last CBS poll before last month's debate on Fox News to 27 percent in the survey released Tuesday.
However, Carson's support increased from 6 to 23 percent during the same period.
The poll also found that Carson was doing well in demographic groups, with support among college-educated Republican voters was much higher than Trump.
The rest, apart from Carly Fiorina and Ohio Governor John Kasich, have fallen from the 10% support level last month to 2% now, including Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker.
Former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, and Florida Senator Marco Rubio are in third place with 6 percent each.
The margin of error for this most recent poll of 376 Republican voters was plus or minus 6% and was conducted in September.
An CNN/ORC survey released last week showed Carson's support among Republicans at 19 percent, putting him just behind Trump's 32 percent.
The latest poll, conducted by ABC News/Washington Post, also shows Trump significantly ahead of Carson.
Trump, who found himself up against Carson's rise last week, apologized to the retired brain surgeon for questioning his faith, but continued to randomly poke him.
During a campaign stop in Iowa on Saturday, Trump said "we need energy".
Five fraternity members at Baruch College charged in the death of a first-year student
Murder charges were filed against five people, almost two years after a college student died at a fraternity pledging ceremony in the Pocono Mountains of Pennsylvania.

In September 2013, members of the Pi Delta Psi fraternity at New York City's Baruch College allegedly attacked Chun "Michael" Deng during a hazing ritual and contributed to his death by delaying calling for medical attention, according to police.
Authorities said his eyes were blindfolded, he had a 30-pound sandbag strapped to his back, and he kept running into barbed wire as he tried to walk across the frozen field to his target.
Mr Deng said his head began to hurt and he later lost consciousness and then filed a complaint.
Members of the Pi Delta Psi fraternity did not call 911 until after Deng fell unconscious and waited an hour before bringing him to the hospital, according to police.

But according to Police Commissioner Chris Wagner, who spoke at a press conference, the fraternity brothers then changed Deng's clothes, looked up his symptoms on Google and contacted the national president of the fraternity, Andy Meng, for advice.
Commisioner Wagner said at this point, the members started to put their personal belongings and started to put their own self interests ahead of Michael Deng's well-being.
He could not be resuscitated, and he passed away the following morning.
An autopsy report shows that Deng suffered repeated blunt-force trauma to the head, body and buttocks.

Douglas Fierberg, an attorney representing Deng's family, said in a statement that 'as a result of fraternity initiation rituals, many families have been shattered and at least one student has died every year since 1970.'
Fraternities and their members must be held accountable, and this step is a very important one by authorities.
The grand jury of Monroe County recommended that criminal charges of third-degree murder be filed against the first five members.
Thirty-two gang members, including Meng, will be charged with racketeering, including the initiation ceremony attack, as well as other crimes.
Wagner said at a press conference on Tuesday that not only those involved, but also organizations that officially or unofficially accepted responsibility would also be held accountable.
Baruch College banned the fraternity, and the national fraternity also severed its relationship with the local chapter.
What happens when the Federal Reserve raises the interest rates?
The bull market collapses as interest rates rise, bond yields climb, and the economy slides into recession.
We know that.
What we do not know is how long it will take and how long it will go on.
History, especially in economics, gives very little information about timing.
The retrenchment has been as brief as 11 months after the first interest rate increase, as well as as lengthy as 86 months.
The Fed's aggressiveness in raising interest rates has often been a decisive factor in the response of the economy and financial assets, though not always.
That is why Fed officials have been stressing that investors should focus not on when rates will start to rise but on how long the process of normalization will take.
It is a fact that there are various variables.
The result, however, could be that market participants think the rate hike frenzy is overblown.

In a note to clients, Julian Jessop, global chief economist of Capital Economics, said: "Some are bound to interpret the Fed's first interest rate rise since the global financial crisis as signalling the end of the era of cheap money."
Contrary to this, we don't expect the US interest rates to return to a more normal level soon, but it has been seen that most of the levels that are still low are the seismic shock that frightened.
Still, we cannot say that it will not have any effects.
Based on past trends, here are the reactions that some areas of the economy can give:
As we have seen in the past months, expecting interest rates to rise could make some things temporarily imbalanced.
There is not such a dramatic effect when interest rates are increased.

Analysts from Deutsche Bank say in a new research about what will happen after the interest rate hikes, "A 12-24 month pause in core earnings growth has been the trend following the last initial rate hike, which could reflect the pause in monetary policy."

According to a recent analysis shared by Bob Doll, an analyst at Nuveen Asset Management, the market generally recorded sharp increases - around 14 percent - over the last 35 years, and then continued in a straight line towards interest rate increases, 250 days later (an average of 2.6 percent increase), and then returned to normal, 500 days later, and delivered an average return of 14.4 percent in the last six cycles.
Deutsche said the impact on shares could be more pronounced as the interest-rate cycle moves into its next phase and dividends are wiped out.
Setbacks are a reality of economic life, but rate increases help them, too.
The Fed is currently facing some situations it has not experienced before, which could worsen the recession.
The most striking thing is that the gross domestic product, which is not adjusted for inflation, is at its lowest level so far for the Fed to raise interest rates.
According to Deutsche Bank, in 118 interest rate increases since 1950, nominal nominal annual gross domestic product only fell below 4.5 percent two times.
While real GDP expanded at a 3.6% annual rate in the second quarter, the Atlanta Fed's GDPNow model sees only moderate growth ahead. Its forecast for the third quarter is 1.5%.
According to Deutsche, raising interest rates in such a sensitive economic environment could be risky and raise the question of "will it be different this time".
The attention of market participants who have been waiting for a year for the Fed to raise interest rates will be on the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which will end on Thursday.
While most strategy experts and economists believe the FOMC can approve an increase at this meeting, futures trading is pointing to only a 25% likelihood.

According to the report, "in all the inflation cycles we have seen since 1950, this time around the expansion has been within a supercycle of rising trend and real GDP has recovered quickly to the previous peak after the start of the recovery."
To the contrary, this is a recovery unmatched by any previous recovery in the example period for the slowness of the worst recession on record.
The current cycle is the longest the Fed has waited since the last recession - the longest ever cycle on record was 35 months and the current cycle is currently in its 74th month.
Fixed income became less stable with the expectation of interest rate hike in the market and is looking like a copy of our own equity.
What's more, the impact of the Fed changing its policy is felt more quickly in the bond markets than in the stock markets.
When the first rise/drop of the cycle comes, bond yields do not immediately change direction.
" At the end of the rate-hike cycle, bond yields instantly fall, " Deutsche said.
Charles Schwab strategists say the increases will flatten the yield curve by bringing yields closer together on longer- and shorter-dated bonds.
While Kathy Jones, an analyst from Schwab analysts who say that high-yielding bonds in general perform better in such an environment, she still says "we remain cautious about reaching for yield."
Interestingly, Jones thinks the markets have already adapted to the Fed's policy expectations.
"In addition to the strength of the dollar and the decline in inflation expectations, there are various signals that the market is being reorganized according to tighter monetary policy," he wrote.

Short-term interest rates are rising, the yield curve is flattening, credit spreads are widening, and volatility is increasing - all of the characteristics that will be observed in the market when the Fed tightens policy.
Looking at the big picture, companies that do most of their business in the United States will benefit if interest rates rise and make local products more attractive.
The situation will be worse for highly-indebted multinational companies, as rising dollar makes the products more expensive in the global market, and their debts will be more expensive.
Goldman Sachs analysts said in a report prepared for their clients that, "History shows that 'quality' stocks can underperform at the beginning of such a rise."
Companies with strong balance sheets had outperformed those with weaker balance sheets by an average of 5 percent after rate increases in 1994, 1999 and 2004.
Companies with stocks of high capitalization and low volatility also outperformed their low-quality competitors, with a mean of 3-4 percent.
Debt will become a huge issue.
Goldman says that companies with a high proportion of floating-rate debt are most vulnerable to losses.
In addition to a pure gambling, shoppers are expected to benefit from the growing dollar.
Although experts disagree on how fast you should teach yourself, savers can also profit from big gains.

Andrew Bingham said BBC Radio 3 is a copy of Classic FM
""")
Conservative MP Andrew Bingham accused the station of "vulgarising itself".
He argued that the radio was becoming more and more like its commercial rivals.
He also accused the BBC Music Awards of aiming at the Brits Awards.
His colleague Damien Collins has blamed The Voice for not being original.

A prominent representative said that he was putting pressure on the broadcaster in order to highlight the difference between BBC Radio 3 and other commercial stations, saying that it was "increasingly turning into Classic FM".
Conservative MP Andrew Bingham also told BBC bosses that the radio station was "going downmarket" and was increasingly indistinguishable from its commercial rivals.
He said: "I hate that term but Radio 3 has gone downmarket, it's turning into Classic FM."
Besides, it also aims at the BBC Music Awards, which was held last December.
The BBC Music Awards are basically another version of the Brit Awards, which were launched last year.
Bingham said, "So if you're trying to do something different, those are my first two examples, but you're just going to copy what's already out there in the market."
The BBC's general manager defended BBC Radio 3 and said that it is far ahead of its commercial rivals, both in live music and in popular education.
If I am learning it from Radio 3, I don't go somewhere else to learn something else about classical music.
And this is devotion to live music, making music is incomparable with anything else.
He also said he thinks it's important Radio 3's effort to discover new music and promote their work.

The head of BBC Radio 3, Alan Davey, said at the beginning of the year that the station had to work harder to reach a wider audience, because Britons were less educated in the field of classical music than the past.
However, Radio 3 is not the only BBC part that has been in the firing line at the Committee's meeting on Culture, Media and Sport.
MP Tory Damien Collins also lashed out at The Voice - the music talent show which the BBC bought the copyright for from Dutch production company Talpa Media for 22 million pounds.
Can't you see why the program is so controversial? Because it is not original and it doesn't have a special difference.
Lord Hall insisted that the BBC1 show, which was juried by Paloma Faith and Boy George, was in a "distinctive BBC style".
He said that the institution should find a hit in its own blood before it produces another entertainment program.
However, he did not agree that the idea of preventing more shows like O Ses or spending the license fee on other genres should be accepted.
Is Black Friday the reason behind the August internet sales experienced the lowest increase in history?
For the first three months of 2015, there was a seven percent increase in online sales
The slowest growth was recorded since the year 2000, when records began to be broken last month.
Three years ago, a boom happened in online sales when mobile devices started to be used for shopping.
Experts point out that Black Friday in November could be the reason for decreased spending.
On-line shopping has been growing at phenomenal rates for more than a decade and turning many of Britain's most vibrant shopping streets into ghost towns.
After figures show that online sales grew just seven percent in the first three months of 2015, experts are warning that online sales are showing signs of weakening further.
There was only a five percent increase over last year in the amount of spending in August, and the lowest growth since 2000, when records began to be broken.
After the figures show that in the first three months of 2015 there was only a one percent growth in internet sales, experts indicate that internet sales are giving more and more signs of weakness.

"If you look at the growth rates of previous years and particularly the year 2000, you'll see that everything is actually coming back to normal," IMRG sales index editor Andy Mulcahy told The Guardian.
He also added that internet sales grew dramatically three years ago when people started using their cell phones to buy products.
This meant more shoppers who could even shop while they were lying on the sofa.
But right now it's flat, you can see the decline.
The phenomenon of Black Friday, an American concept, is being pointed out as one of the reasons for the slowdown in sales.
Experts say that shoppers may have been waiting for this event, which took place on the last Friday of November, to buy something.
Last year, a five-fold increase in the number of consumers rushing to the company's websites to get cheap products compared to the previous year led to the collapse of many sites.
Experts say that Black Friday may have 'tamed' shoppers for now, as footage showed customers fighting over bargains
According to a research published by the British Retail Consortium, one of every five pounds spent on shopping is spent on purchases on the internet.
One third of some products such as TV and washing machine are now purchased from online stores.
Also, more than one quarter of the people buy their clothes and shoes from the internet rather than from luxurious and flashy shopping malls.
Muslims bid farewell to the victims of the crane accident in Mecca, which was found guilty of the Bin Ladin family.
After the first funerals held in Mecca, the bodies of the 29 people who lost their lives were carried through the streets by Muslims
Saudi Arabia holds construction giant Saudi Binladin Group responsible for the crane crash that occurred
The Health Ministry has announced that 394 people have been injured in total after the collapse of the crane.
Hundreds of Muslims gathered to carry the bodies of 29 people who lost their lives when a crane collapsed in Masjid al-Haram.
The majority of the crowd, mostly whites, blocked the roads to bid their first farewells to their last journeys in the Muaysım cemetery in Mecca.
The grief- stricken crowd passed through the holy site where the tragedy occurred in which the pilgrims were crushed after the roof of a crane collapsed a few days ago.

Following the bin Laden family, which owns the construction holding of the Saudi Kingdom, taking the responsibility for the event where 394 people were also wounded, the bodies of the deceased were brought in to be buried.

Experts criticise the e-cigarette research of UK Public Health

Researchers, who were reported to be part of a 12-member committee that included those connected to the tobacco industry, and was funded by the government, said that e-cigarettes are 95 percent less harmful than smoking cigarettes.
Experts writing in the British Medical Journal (BMJ) joined the Lancet in criticising the evidence cited by Public Health England (PHE) in its report on e-cigarettes.
The PHE published its "landmark" report last month, which it describes as "a detailed examination of the evidence".
But some researchers have questioned the reliability of the data and drawn attention to links between some of the experts and the tobacco industry.
The Lancet medical journal, in an editorial last month, took aim at the "extremely shoddy foundation" of PHE's key conclusion.
Two other researchers writing in the BMJ question the claim that it is based on "firm scientific ground".

Professor Martin McKee of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and Professor Simon Capewell of Liverpool University said: "A fundamental principle of public health is that policies should be based on evidence of effectiveness."
They said that the public would expect PHE's claims that e-cigarettes are "around 95% less harmful than smoking" to be based on a detailed examination of the evidence and modelling.

The conclusion is actually the result of a meeting of 12 people to develop a multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) model to synthesize their views on the harms of e-cigarettes and other nicotine-containing products; the outcomes of the meeting have been summarized in a research article.

McKee and Capewell said that one of the sponsors of the meeting is a company called EuroSwiss Health, which was reported to have received funding from British American Tobacco for an independent research project undertaken by its director general.
They also said that he approved a sustainability report which endorsed BAT's public health document.

The meeting included 12 people, one of whom reported that they had received funds from an e-cigarette manufacturer, but they said this was not the same funding that was previously reported to have been received from the cigarette company Philip Morris International.
No information was given about how panel members were selected, but some of them reported in the article as having industry funding including some known giants of e-cigarettes.
Others present at the meeting are not known for their expertise on tobacco control.
The head of tobacco in PHE also attended the meeting.
McKee and Capewell acknowledged that the group's research paper "lacked concrete evidence of harm for most products by many criteria in a way that was effective."
But none of these connections or limitations are discussed in the PHE report.
Mckee and Capewell said that claims that e-cigarettes are a transition to smoking for children or non-smokers were "very premature".
In the PHE, the director of health and well-being Prof Kevin Fenton said that the claims in the BMJ were responded earlier.
"E-cigarettes are considerably less harmful than smoking" she said.
One of two people who are lifelong cigarette addicts dies because of his addiction.
All the evidence is pointing to the fact that e-cigarettes cause much less health risks when compared to cigarettes, but we need to continue to follow-up on the long-term effects.
PHE has a clear mission: to inform the public, especially at a time when there is much confusion about the risks, about what the evidence shows and does not show.
Nearly 80,000 people die each year from smoking-related illnesses and smoking costs the NHS £2 billion a year.
By spelling out the existing evidence - that e-cigarettes are not risk-free but carry only a fraction of the harm caused by smoking - we are meeting our national responsibility.

Sonogenetics enables the control of brain cells with sound waves
The video shows how the spiders change direction when they are hit by the sound vibrations.
Scientists have raised crickets with genetically engineered nervous systems that can be controlled by sound wave pulses.
The minute wire worms change direction when they are hit by the vibrations of sound that humans cannot hear.
They are operated by inserting genetically modified motor nerve cells that contain ion channels that respond to vibrations, eliciting ultrasonic waves.
Related: Researchers are reading and writing with brain activity
Researchers said the mites demonstrated the power of a new procedure dubbed sonogenetics, that allows ultrasonic to activate a range of brain, heart and muscle cells from outside the body.

Sreekanth Chalasani, a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California, told the Guardian that one day, this procedure may be replaced by an invasive procedure called deep-brain stimulation, which involves placing electrodes in the brain to deliver electrical pulses that can treat the symptoms of Parkinson's disease.
Threadworms don't usually respond to sound, but Chalasani found that they did respond when surrounded by a liquid containing microscopic bubbles.
The bubbles he finds strengthen the ultrasonic waves and thus allow the mites to pass through.
The amplified ultrasound waves affect structures on the cell membranes of certain tick cells, called TRP-4 ion channels.
According to a report published in Nature Communications, sound waves cause these ion channels to open and activate the cells to which they are attached.
To create sound-controlled worms, Chalasani has genetically modified the worms to have some of their motor neurons express the TRP-4 ion channel.
When he applied ultrasound to the converted creatures, sound waves were amplified by micro-bubbles and transmitted into the worms and here converted motor neurons were activated.
This procedure is similar to optogenetics, a groundbreaking tool that allows researchers to switch neurons on and off with flashes of light.
But Chalasani says that there may be some advantages to this technique over sonogenetics.

Unlike light which needs to be sent by an optical fiber to the desired point in the brain, infrasound waves can pass through tissue without obstruction and they can be sent to the inside of the brain from the skull.

Chalasani said "we believe that through gene therapy and by using a therapeutic virus, human neurons targeted for specific neurological treatments can be made temporarily sensitive to supersonic signals in a clinical setting".
He added that other applications could focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells.

Eight golden rules for living in student dormitories

11 years ago I moved into student accommodation as a disinterested 19 year old, and I still believe in berets and moral relativism, but now I remember the fake smiles of my housemates - and the endless litany of complaints about everyone else.
Most of what I learned can be distilled into eight golden rules.
Moving home can range from irritating to completely terrifying.

The allure of chit-chat: Where are you from, did you lose a year, where did you insist on Corbyn and why, "I'm frankly Marmite, I don't love or hate it because it's really yeast extract HAHAHAH I'm going to be in my room."
Take a deep breath.
And let the others have one, too - ask questions and show interest.

This will guide your conversation and help you distinguish who you do like from those people you don’t like and that you would not talk to even if your eyelashes were on fire and they had the fire extinguisher.
Give people a little space.
People's rooms often turn into venues for drinks reception, cinema nights and hangout points, but they are also the places where people change and adjust their underwear.
Related: Don't even think about starting college with a relationship
Introverts are mistreated at the university.
Your room might be an oasis of solitude, but many halls of residence nurture a culture of hanging around in the corridors, which is very friendly, social and opens up to friendships for life.
This might be hell for someone trying to conserve their energy.
The culture does not allow you to say “I like you and I want our friendship to continue, but I need a break so that I can recharge the energy I spend when communicating with you”.
Try to sense when a friend is tired of socializing and maybe text instead of knocking on the door.
Speaking of knocking on the door: do it.
A student at the dorm has adopted the policy of if the door is not locked, it is an invitation to come in.
He has seen a lot.
Making friends by way of cooking.

At the height of the food competition craze, it would be less weird and less 1950s "welcome to the neighborhood, I baked you something, now smile at me while I ask you personal questions" to introduce yourself by banging on people's doors with a pan of brownies.
Offering homemade treats to people is a great way to make friends.
Your roommates might feel obliged to speak, and perhaps they will associate your face with a sweet surprise.
Yes, it's all about you being a master chef.
The dough, sugar and oil not well mixed, when you knock at the door, will cause them to pretend to be asleep.
Stealing food is a very common crime in the dormitories.
To be honest, it is stealing to steal a chicken, but is it stealing to take a few drops of milk for your tea?
Check the milk owner twice.
He is likely to tell you to get a life of your own, even if he is swimming in it.
It is very annoying when someone steals your things and I understand that you are upset but try to deal with it more maturely than my dorm mate did. He poured liquid soap on it to punish the thief.
He is in prison now.
Do not make noise that will disturb people from sleeping or studying.
This is not only to be a good person, but also because you are einsanlar in the glass houses.
A girl in my corridor told her neighbour next door to turn the drums down a bit because it was 3 o'clock in the morning and she had an exam the next morning.
The answers were to turn the sound up.

They finally closed the restaurant at 5 a.m. and the girl, after turning on her music at full volume and locking the door, politely gave them two hours to sleep before she went off to the three-hour exam.
Wouldn’t it be romantic if your future spouse were to move into the same corridor with you?

On the other hand, wouldn't it be strange if you get the wrong impression of a corridor friend and think she is going to be your future wife, come on to her, split up with her and have to see her every day and watch your common friends get taken hostage?
Of course the heart wants what it wants, but if your fiery corridor neighbor is definitely not your future spouse, at least talk to your child and recommend common sense.
Be aware that the line between good natured fun and hurting someone is thinner than you think when you find yourself locking someone inside a room with their keys on the other side.
A good joke is fun but will take time to return.
You can teach someone a valuable and fun lesson on security by hiding their things, but never, ever clog someone's room with shampoo and toothpaste.
Lock your doors and freeze your key in a cup of water, but don't stick your things to the ceiling more than twice.

Oil companies officially in ruins

From the moment that oil prices began to fall in 2014 to the end of last year, around 400 billion dollars worth of investment has been deferred, with the most projects being put on hold being deep sea oil exploration.

According to a study by consulting firm Wood Mackenzie, low oil prices have led to the suspension of $380 billion worth of oil and gas exploration and production projects, from the Gulf of Mexico to Africa, with millions of barrels' worth of production also being delayed across a broad geography.
The report said that cost cuts were the largest reason for decline and that "company budgets have become dramatically tighter" as oil prices fell 70% from $115 a barrel in June 2014.
400 BILLION DOLLARS IN SUSPENSE
Crude oil prices continue to surprise, falling to their lowest level in 12 years below $30, a level not seen since 2003.

An analysis released by energy consultancy Wood Mackenzie as the debate on whether oil will fall to $15 or become cheaper than water heats up shows how the sector is being affected by the fall in prices.

Finally, in the report it published in July, Wood Mackenzie showed that falling oil prices caused 46 major energy investments worth 200 billion dollars to be suspended, and in its new study it reveals where the number will reach by the end of 2015.
According to this, 22 major projects were postponed in the last six months of 2015, and a total of 68 major projects have been postponed since the decline in oil prices began in 2014.
The value of these projects is around 400 billion.
2.9 million barrels are produced daily.
The research, which highlights that the impact of the low oil prices on company plans is "cruel," notes that the most affected projects are deep-water development projects.
The put-on-hold projects will amount a total of 27 billion barrels of oil equivalent, while the daily production of 2.9 million barrels is being delayed until 2025.
According to the study, most of the projects in question were postponed to 2017 and later, while the first production targets were also postponed to 2020-2023.

The report emphasised that 170 billion dollars worth of potential investment, which is planned to be made in the next five years, is included in the 68 postponed projects, and said, "The majority of 170 billion dollars is deep sea projects."
This is also because the upfront investment cost is very high.
"Deepwater spending is also led by projects in Nigeria, Angola, and the US Gulf of Mexico, a 70% share of the total."
According to the research, the countries having the inventory of most delayed oil projects are Canada, Angola, Kazakhstan, Nigeria, Norway and the USA.
These six countries, in turn, account for nearly 90 percent of the world's proven oil reserves.
Mozambique, Australia, Malaysia and Indonesia which have the largest amount of delayed gas reserves, make up together approximately 85 percent of the total.

While most of the natural gas waiting to be brought ashore here is found in deep water, complex and expensive development solutions such as building a new liquefied natural gas (LNG) plant are required.

While it is stated that the most exposed companies are deepwater, Canadian oil sands and Caspian Sea oil-major companies that have one after another commitments, it is also said that companies are attempting to adapt to the "lower for longer" oil price scenario.
IRANIANS EYE

It was not long ago that the picture was like this: The US and Europe imposed sanctions on Iranian oil to stop Tehran's nuclear program, the oil price was about $110 per barrel, and there was discussion about how to cut Iranian oil exports without causing a sudden spike in prices.
When we return to this week, however, we see an entirely different scenario.
Oil prices have dropped below the 30 dollar mark for the first time since 2004, and the main reason for this is the explosion in production in the US and the lifting of sanctions against Iran.
Therefore, the eyes are on Iran.
If Iran increases its oil exports, then even more oil will have flowed into a market that is already declared to be well-saturated.
This could also help prices to go down to levels that would shock us today.
Some analysts say Saudi Arabia will pump even more oil as it wants to defend its market share against Iran, and a price war could start between Iran and Saudi Arabia.
It is noted that Iran's main target once the sanctions are lifted is the rapidly growing oil market of Asia, India and old partners in Europe.
Iranian officials had previously said they wanted to increase exports by 500 thousand barrels per day in the first stage and release as much more into the market at a later time.

According to Reuters shipping data, at least 13 out of 22 very large crude carriers (VLCCs) sitting in the Gulf awaiting a buyer are fully or partly laden, suggesting several million barrels are stuck in Iran.
Iran is the world's fourth largest proven oil reserves.
Through exceptions to the sanctions, Iran is still able to export approximately one million barrels of crude oil daily to countries including Turkey.
Before the sanctions, Iran's daily oil exports had risen as high as 3 million barrels a day.

Aysun Göksu, research specialist of Destek Securities, replies to the question, ‘Will oil price go below 20 dollars?’ as follows: ‘While the concerns over global growth centering on China increase the downward pressure on commodity prices, they cause the losses in oil prices to deepen.’
With concerns that falling economic growth in China, the world's biggest oil importer, will lead to a decline in demand, we see that oil has lost 20% of its value since the beginning of the year.
In addition, due to the global increase of the value of the dollar and the global surplus supply, we can expect oil prices go below 30 dollars.
As long as we do not have any permanent price moves above 32-33 dollars, uptrend movement could be limited in petroleum, and downward pressure could increase.
At this point, it can be said that the critical 30 dollar closing level has a key role in the continuation of the falls.
In such a case, the weakening that occurred down to the support level of 23.30-25.60 at the bottom should not be considered a surprise.

Who is Bergen?
Bergen, whose real name is Belgin Sarılmışer, was born on the 16th of July in 1960 in Mersin.
After his parents' divorce, he moved to Ankara with his mother in 1966, who was Sebahat Çakır.
He entered the Piano Department of Ankara State Conservatory after Yunus Emre Elementary School in Yenimahalle, but left due to financial difficulties and worked at PTT for some time to earn money.
After performing at Feyman Night Club in 1979, where he went with his friends to have fun, he accepted the invitation to play there.
Feyman took the stage with the Grup Lokomotif Orchestra with repertoires consisting of Turkish Art Music, Turkish light music, and arrangements of the era's fashions at the Feyman Night Club.
Bergen met Halis Serbes in Adana and married him a year later.
In 1982, he released his first long-play record, "I Have Complaints."
Bergen could not withstand the violence of her husband while she was having success in her artistic life, and she ran away from her husband many times.
While she was working in İzmir in October 1982, her husband forced her to put acid on her face.

Bergen, who lost one eye and burned a large portion of his body in the attack, was convinced by the composer Cengiz Özşeker, who made Kibariye famous with the song "Who Knows?", to go on stage after treatment.

The artist, who performed at the İzmir Pırlanta Pavyon (İzmir Diamond Pavilion) that Özşeker owned until 1985, prepared a demo cassette titled "We Are Brothers, Destiny" together with his patron and sent it to Yaşar Kekeva.
Kekeva, who likes Bergen, invited the artist to Istanbul.

The artist recorded her first professional longplay "İnsan Severse" in the Istanbul music market, under the musical direction of Burhan Bayar, and she gained fame with "Acıların Kadını" which she recorded in the late 1980s.
The album was praised a lot and the record company awarded her with the "The Best Selling Women's Arabesque Album of 1986" Golden Record and Golden Cassette Awards in April 1987.
In the same year, she appeared in the "Acıların Kadını" movie, written and directed by Ülkü Erakalın, and she acted with Yalçın Gülhan, Asuman Arsan, and Meral Niron.
Bergen, who has a big fan base, narrowly escaped a knife attack in Adana, where he went to give a concert.

Having quit the show business for a while, the artist released three albums entitled "Onu da Yak Tanrım", "Sevgimin Bedeli" and "İstemiyorum", which were directed by the masters Selami Şahin, Özer Şenay and Cengiz Tekin respectively.
Bergen, separated from her husband, officially in April 1989, returned to the stages in June 1989 with her last album "Years do not forgive"
The artist, whose album was greeted with great interest, was shot by his divorced wife during the night of August 14-15, 1989, while he was away on the promotional tour of his album, and was killed.
He was buried in his hometown of Mersin.
Bergen managed to pack his 29 years of life with 5 long-plays, 11 cassettes and 129 songs, and a video film.

The claims that the artist, who left his mark on the Black sea music with his unique and powerful voice, became a legend were confirmed by the fact that the album "Giden Gençliğim" (My lost youth) released after his death was sold out on the day it was released.
Bergen's officially released studio albums:
1982 - I have a complaint LP (re-released in 1986 as MC.)
1983 - Kardeşiz Kader LP (Reissued on MC in 1985 and 1990.)
1985 - İnsan Severse LP, MC (Reissued on CD in 1999.)
1986 - A Woman of Pains LP, MC (Reissued in 1999 as a CD.)
1987 - I Burned God LP, MC (Re-released on CD in 1999.)
1988 - The Price of My Love (re-issued on CD in 1999)
1988 - I don't want LP, MC (1999, re-released as CD.)
1989 - Yıllar Affetmez (Originally the last album.) MC (Reissued in 1999 as a CD.)
1990 - My Youth Gone MC (re-released on CD in 1999.)
1990 – The Distress of the Poor Ends with Death MC (re-released as CD in 1999)
1991 - The Last Cry of Mine MC, CD
Nazım Hikmet was commemorated on his 114th birthday.
The 114th anniversary of the birth of Nazım Hikmet Ran, known as the Poet of the Country, was commemorated with the event "Thank you for Being Born, Nazım".
The event organized by Konak Municipality was held at the hall named after the poet in the Güzelyalı Culture Center.
The event featured poetry and music performances, where famous poet's poems were recited by theatre and cinema actor Rüştü Asyalı.
In the event, the Asian music group accompanied Asyalı with their interpretations.
Many art lovers attended the Nazım Hikmet event.
Among these names are Ali Seçkiner Alıcı, Erkoç Torun, Nedim Yıldız, Zeynep Göknur Yıldız and Ziya Özsökmenler.
An event organized by the Nazim Hikmet Culture and Arts Foundation was held in İstanbul.
The Foundation President Rutkay Aziz and members, Nazim Hikmet's wife Vera Tulyakova's daughter, son-in-law and grandson, actor Tarık Akan gathered in Tarabya for the event.
They will read poems with the slogan "To live like a tree alone and free / Like a forest in brotherhood" and leave carnations in the sea.
The event took place with the contributions of the Sarıyer Municipality and the Nazım Hikmet Chorus performed.
Nazım Hikmet was born on January 15, 1902.
The poems of the world-famous poet Nazım Hikmet were translated into more than 50 languages.
He was arrested many times because of his political ideas and spent most of his adult life in prison or exile.
His poems have been translated into more than 60 languages, and his works have won many awards.
He died on June 3, 1963.
Bursa Nilüfer Municipality carried out special works for the 114th birthday of the famous poet Nazım Hikmet.
The municipality, which has been working on a documentary about Nazim's 11-year Bursa prison days called "Nazim of Bursa", also issued the first personal coin in Turkish history for the poet.
Thus, Turkey's first personal stamp with Nazım Hikmet's name on it was released in cooperation with the PTT.
The special stamps and the first day cover, which have a price of 1.40 TL, will be given to the guests at the event, which will be held on Thursday, January 14, at Nazım Hikmet Culture Center.
To be deported by bicycle
Unable to reach an agreement with their two home nations, the mostly Syrian refugees will now have to pedal back across the border into Russia, in temperatures as low as minus 20 degrees Celsius.
A group of refugees flew to Russia in the summer months, citing that it is safer and cheaper, and then traveled north through the country and traversed from Murmansk to Norway from here.
Migrants were crossing the border on their bicycles, as the agreement between the two countries did not allow the crossing of the border on foot.
Norway now decided to send them back.
For this reason, Norwegian custom officers have given the order to repair the bikes left behind after crossing the border.
The "3 billion euro for Turkey" crisis in EU

What are the advantages of steaming?
Steam cooking, a technique that does not kill the vitamins and minerals in the foods, is becoming more popular.
This steaming method, which has been preferred for centuries in the Far East, strengthens metabolism and aids digestion.
This method completely eliminates problems like indigestion, and also completely kills all bacteria and microorganisms in the food.
The protein, cellulose, and starch in the food completely dissolve with this technique, which makes the food more tender.
The steam cooking takes place under low pressure; it is done in a pot or using a steamer.
In high-pressure cooking, the amount of water used and the cooking time is minimal.
The best example of this can be shown through cooking in a pressure cooker.
Especially we need to wash vegetables like diet menu foods well and then put them into the filter and wait until they are completely drained.
A deep pan is filled with a third of water and the steamer is placed inside the pan.
The top of the pot is left half-covered.
In this way, the steam can easily escape from the pot.
First the fireplace heat is raised to the highest level for the water to boil, then the fireplace heat is lowered again for a steady temperature.
The vegetables and food are wrapped in a papillote and baked in steam for about 10 to 15 minutes until they are thoroughly cooked, and then they are checked with a fork.
The cooked vegetables are taken from the stove and arranged on plates in order to be served.
In the steam cooking technique, the food's appearance, color and smell do not change, so this method is healthy.
The food keeps its unique taste.
Thus the quality and taste of the food is not compromised.
In steaming, one of the most economical methods of cooking, loss of nutrients is also kept to a minimum.
Steamed vegetables look more alive and fresh, and also offer a feast for the eyes for the viewer.
This method, which is frequently used especially in diet food, is often chosen because it is light.
David Bowie - Blackstar: The alien's "final" album
Knowing that you will die; recording that final album while hiding it from the people, making your deathbed into an artistic expression field in the music video you made...
Such jobs may look "too out there" for us earth-bound mortals.
I say aliens because I am among those who believe that the man who did this was both immortal and alien.
She had come to our world from another corner of the universe, now she was returning to her homeland, that was all.
He came because there was an inspiration that should be given to all the World artists, not just Kiss, Marilyn Manson or Lady Gaga.
He completed his duty.
David Bowie, Blackstar, iTunes price: 9.99 TL 5/5
He drew inspiration from Warhol and Kubrick, who are probably from the same planet as him.
When Apollo 11 landed on the moon, it decided to go “Is that all? I am an extraterrestrial” and joined us by singing “Space Oddity”.
Actually, it did not work, it always went a few steps ahead.
Many people found their lost ways with his help.
Both musician and listener...
It is not fair to say "It was only music" for his music, if we put his acting and interest in plastic arts aside.
For me, [his] discography expresses an artistic unity with the way it moves from song to song and the characters created by himself; with its references and novelty, breaking taboos.
I cannot call him father of glam rock or a cousin of punk...
What would happen to the jazz he loves so much since his childhood if he were to get carried away with avant-garde electronic movements?
David Bowie reminded us of what the word icon meant until we learned to use it in our mouths in these days.
It was not a man, it was not a woman; it was not a human.
It was one body.
He appeared to us for a while for a mission.
That body left this world two days after his 26th studio album "Blackstar" was released.
"Blackstar" and "Lazarus", which we listened to before the album was released, tried to get us used to where we were going.
We thought "It's getting old, talking about the death", he was aware of everything.
One more game ...

We can say the number of songs we know on the album when it was released including "Blackstar" and "Lazarus" which carry the message and emotional load of the album along with "Sue (Or In A Season Of Crime)" and "'Tis A Pity She Was A Whore" which were published much earlier but were re-edited and recorded for this album.
I would like to say that the rest of them - i.e. "Girl Loves Me", "I Can't Give Everything Away" and "Dollar Days" are all very good songs as well.
Blackstar is built on a very strong musical structure but it is also as sincere and immediate as if it were composed by momentary feelings.
Neither death nor a "past catching up" album...
Just a true final album.
The End of a Masterpiece Musical Life.

ISIS is using Alrawi instead of Whatsapp
According to a new report, the terror organization ISIS is using its own messaging tool to communicate independently, without relying on chat apps like WhatsApp and Telegram.

This Android application called "Alrawi" is distributed and loaded through an APK file.
The application allows organization to message and share media in an encrypted way among themselves.
IŞİD makes a bold move in Iraq

How should the semester break be utilized?
We asked education expert and student coach Murat Aydın how students should spend their mid-term break.
The half-term holiday should not be thought of as a time just for relaxation, amusement, watching television and spending time at the computer for students.
The mid-term vacation is a very important opportunity to prepare for the new term of education and review the past one.
The so-called free time, or half-term holiday, is also an important opportunity to develop personality, acquire knowledge, skills and hobbies.
Make a list of the things you will improve on in the second half of the semester.
Write down and try to apply everything that you plan to do and everything that you plan.
I am sure you will enjoy it and have a very productive semester.
Now let's talk about what kind of a productive semester it should be for the student friends who are preparing for YGS and LYS tests.

Because the questions we get from friends who are preparing for the university entrance exam are mostly about how to spend this period; should we solve lots of questions, or should we fix our missing topics?
Let us begin our article with advice for the friends who are studying for the exam to be able to respond to these questions and also to pass this period efficiently.

Preparation for the exam should normally start in the 9th grade, but we try to complete it mostly within the last year, and this makes our last year more effective, productive, and forces us to spend our time more wisely.
The student of the last class has to work for the examinations and for the school writings at the same time.
Even though a graduate student has taken (YGS-LYS) at least one time and experienced it, the year of preparation for the test as a graduate student also carries critical importance for that student.
Because most postgraduate students and their families view the year 'O' as the last chance and this creates even more stress.

Studying for a class is an activity that students usually do only when they are forced to or feel that they have to, and they generally leave it until the last minute, but for students who are regular and make it a habit, it has become a task and they have a plan of what to do and when to do it.
There is the mid-semester holiday ahead of us and we should make the best of it.
For this, we must have a plan that will allow us to manage our time well.
Studying During the Mid-term Break:
Everyone should make a plan according to their situation.
What was completed in the first period, what was left out; one must plan the day, the week, and the 15 days ahead.
There should be both topic reviews and question solutions in this period.
Also, students who are not very behind can solve 1-2 practice tests on average.
Get Caught Up: Studies show that people forget 75% of what they learn in a week, 66% of what they learn in a day, and 54% of what they learn in an hour.
The best and most effective way to eliminate forgetting is the repetition.
Students who make a lot of mistakes, especially on past tense subjects, should focus on general review.
First identify your missing topics and plan them day by day, assign topics to each day and make sure to handle them.
This planning will calm you down both academically and psychologically.
When scheduling your test, make sure that the subjects that you make most mistakes in are scheduled at the beginning.
Because you will not have such a long holiday period in the future.

Do the Problem Solutions:
"""
It is as important to do question review as it is to solve questions.
Because we can only see how well we understand our studies through the feedback we get by asking questions.
Don't forget to set a specific question-solving number for each day.

The number of questions you will solve may change according to your studies that day; you may not be able to solve many questions on a day when you study subjects with key topics, but for the sake of seeing how much we learned about the subject of the day, we must do a minimum amount of question solving.
Work on Practice Exams:
Another work you should do during the half-year holidays is solving test exams.
Although not all of the topics are completed, at least you can solve the practice exams.
Let’s say you’ve more or less mastered your Turkish lessons; you can do 40-question Turkish practice tests.
And you should definitely do it while you are timing yourself.
If you can solve the first 40 questions of Turkish in 60 minutes, then your next target, if possible, is to solve them in a few minutes less.
Holiday and Hobby Plan:
Of course, the holidays do not only mean studying; you should also spend some of your time on holidays, rest and your hobbies.
A holiday period filled with only studying will prevent you from decharging and resting.
So, you should allow for special times to yourself in your plans.
Reading books, watching TV, surfing the Internet may be included in your plans, but what is most important is how much time you devote to each.
I also have a small suggestion for those friends who say they did not pass the first phase effectively.
If you say that my first term did not go so well, that I did not work so much, and that I have too many shortcomings, then this winter break is also a great opportunity for you.
But primarily you must decide and believe this.
In the 2009-2010 season of the Turkish football super league, most goals were scored between the 76th and 90th minutes.
Now you answer to the question you asked yourself. Is the match over and are you going to the locker room? Or is the match still going on and you will be able to score in a few minutes?
I think no one wants to hear the classic comment of a defeated football team coach or players, "we are going to look to the next match now."
Now what you have to do is to leave your past behind and not just walk, but run.
In summary, what we are saying is:
First of all, make a semester holiday plan,
2) Go over the topics you know,
Take care of any unfinished business.
4) Do exercises on the topic,
5) Do practice tests,
Read a book.
Set new goals for the new era,
Make time for yourself, your hobbies, and things you enjoy.

Make time for your family and friends
