Do I need to have a gallbladder surgery? - Family - Health News - Zaman Newspaper
Dr. Fevzi Özgönül, answers questions in his column in Meydan Newspaper.
I have a stone in my gallbladder, and every morning when I wake up, after meals, I go to the bathroom 2 or more times with stomach pain.
Could this be what is keeping me from losing weight?
I'm using alkaline now, but my appetite is not reducing, I can't lose weight.
It's been like that since my childhood.
What should I do?
Do you think I should have a gallbladder operation?
ANSWER: Gallstones are often accompanied by an infection.
Complaints of stomachache after meals are also a sign that your gallbladder contracts and ejects bile when you eat.
The intestines that are irritated by the inflammatory bile try to get rid of the bile quickly.
This is why you urinate often.
Frequent trips to the bathroom mean your body doesn't have time to digest the food properly, slowing down weight loss.
I think you should treat this situation.
If you go to a specialist gastroenterologist, and what I said is diagnosed, you can get rid of this condition by taking antibiotics.
But in the end, you might have to have surgery to remove the gall bladder.
Alkaline probiotics can reduce these complaints a bit but not completely.
I would advise that you continue to use alkaline probiotics no matter what.
Because this probiotic powder is the biggest help to lose weight.
I eat a lot when I'm stressed.
My teacher says that when I am stressed and angry I eat, and I gain weight.
How can I cope with this?
The excessive appetite means that you cannot fully meet your energy needs.
The reason may be eating too little or skipping breakfast and lunch.
Another reason is that you cannot digest the food you are eating.
For this, your digestion system has to work properly.
The easiest solution, if you don't have an ulcer, reflux, or similar problem, is to use a good probiotic supplement.
You will see the benefit of it.
I can not gain weight, doctors do not know the reason.
There are usually information about weight loss in your corner.
It all makes sense to me but my situation is a little different.
I can't put on weight.
What's more, I don't know why.
The doctors say nothing.
The techniques we apply are not only for slimming but also for getting back the ideal size by regaining the physiological work of the body.
Obesity and weakness are the same sorts of diseases.
Obesity and underweight are treated with the same technique.
You also lose weight when you eat sweets and pastries.
I think you have probably figured that out by now.
It is possible for you to be stimulated with carboxypuncture and gain weight with healthy nutrition.
In other words, you have moved away from your ideal weight.
Our other patients have become obese, moving far away from their ideal body.
You will reach your ideal body by gaining weight, they by losing weight.
If the systemic problem goes away, you gain weight, they lose weight.
But first things first, the system needs to be working properly.

A child that feels worthless is stuck in 'hate'
There are some feelings which are innate in the human psyche.
Fear, sadness, joy, astonishment, anger, concern...
However, hate and revenge like emotions appear in children over time and as a result of some faulty attitudes.
Every human being needs to be an individual, including during their childhood.
She wants to be respected for her decisions, to be asked her opinion on matters that concern her, and to be made to feel she is valued.
Ensuring these things constitute the foundation of a healthy personality structure.

For example, making decisions on behalf of the child on issues that concern the child (what to wear, what to eat), ignoring children's wishes and imposing their own truths on them (sending a child who wants to go to a football course to instrument training) such behaviors mean not to respect the child's personality.

A child who is not respected in his or her own individuality and existence will lose their freedom to be themselves, and their defensive mechanism will bring out anger and hatred in order to protect themselves.

Psychologist Hilal Arslan says, "Because anger and hate are actually the opposite of accepting." She says the child is not accepting what is happening to him by hating, and she is trying to tell him and his surroundings that he is valuable.

The expert psychologist says that the child's rejection of the situation is a positive development in terms of his personality development, and "the hatred here is to say 'I am also here', it serves the purpose of protecting his self-esteem."
He says, "If children are allowed to be individuals, hatred will disappear."
The child tries to protect his own being by seeking refuge in anger and hate.

Arslan says that the children are most vulnerable when they are at a young age, both physically and psychologically, and that the abuse by parents and the environment may cause negative emotions in children, and points out that neglect makes the child feel like they do not exist and that they are invisible.

Arslan continues: "This can be the failure to fulfill either their emotional needs (hugging, kissing, taking care of their school or other needs), or their physical needs (food, drink, housing, school needs, etc.)."
It is a child-rearing policy that opens the door to anger and hatred.
As for emotional and verbal abuse, there are behaviors such as humiliation, insulting, belittling, scolding, giving unnecessary and severe punishments, making the person feel worthless, and shouting.
This behavior touches a deep place because it is directed toward the child's personality.

"The child either accepts this, loses his self-respect and spends his life struggling with the feeling of being worthless, undeserving of love, and inadequate, or he takes refuge in anger and hatred and tries to defend his own self."

In the 18th week, Galatasaray began preparations for the Mersin İdman Yurdu match that will be played in the Başakşehir Stadium tomorrow.
The soccer club will go to the Constitutional Court for the lost points.

Denizlispor will seek its rights from the Constitutional Court by filing an individual application to the Turkish Football Federation's (TFF) Arbitration Board, which decided to cancel the club's three points because the club did not meet the financial criteria.
Denizlispor President Mustafa Şavluk said that they would go to the Constitutional Court because the decision of the Arbitration Board is final.
Şavluk says, "The judicial remedy is exhausted."
Legal entities can also apply.

The arbitration panel was supposed to render its decision within three months.
 
Q: Bu kanunların uygulanıp uygulanamayacağının önemli olmadığını söylüyor.
A: He says that it doesn't matter whether these laws are implemented or not.
According to the Rules of Arbitration, the reasoned decision should have been published within three months.
It has been four months since we filed our application.
If the Constitutional Court says, "There has been a violation of rights here," then the situation could turn in our favor.
"We will not give up." he said
Şavluk added that the applications might be a first in the sports community.
Not even a storm could stop the passengers of hope
118 illegal immigrants from Syria and Pakistan, who embarked on a journey of hope from Bodrum with a boat and a fishing boat, were rescued by Turkish and Greek Coast Guard teams.

The 105 Syrian refugees, including women and children, who were trying to cross the Greek island of Kilimli (Kalimnos) with a 15-meter fishing boat they took off from Yalıkavak Neighborhood Küdür Site, experienced difficult times when they crashed into the rocky island of Kargı at 04.00 today.
The Turkish Coast Guard teams rescued the Syrian asylum seekers who were stuck on a boat on the rocks with the help of fishermen.
One hundred and five stowaways were taken to Yalıkavak Marina.

The boat which carried the thirteen illegal immigrants from Pakistan and Syria who were trying to cross to the Greek island of Astypalaia (Kos Island) from Turgutreis with a 5-meter rubber boat was swept away due to the storm and the current in the waters of Pserimos Island.
The Greek Coast Guard, which was on patrol at 7:00 in the morning, spotted people in the boat that were in danger of sinking by taking water.
Some of the migrants who fell to the sea were rescued and taken to the island of Kilimli.
At least 20 dead, 15 injured- World News - Zaman Newspaper
At least 20 people were killed and 15 wounded in a bomb and gun attack on a hotel popular with foreigners and the cafeteria next to it in the capital of Burkina Faso, West Africa.
The attack was claimed by a local Maghrebi group with links to Al-Qaeda.
Militants were said to have taken some hostages in the 147-room Splendid Hotel.
The operation by security forces to the hotel 5 hours after the attack is going on.
There are explosions and heavy gunfire coming from the building that no one is approaching.
The partial fire, which broke out in the hotel due to explosives, is still continuing.
How many people are being held hostage inside is not yet known.
It was learned that that hotel is preferred especially by foreigners and United Nations employees.
Yalgado Ouedraogo Hospital administrator Robert Sangare said 20 people died during the siege and 15 people were seriously wounded by bullets. He said they were concerned about the rising death toll.
The temporary president of Burkina Faso was held in custody for a short time during a coup attempt that took place in Burkina Faso last September.
Burkina Faso Prime Minister Paul Kaba Thieba announced his new cabinet three days ago. The President, Roch Marc Christian Kabore also took on Defense Ministry.
Romania is going for transparency in election spending
In Romania, a new bill is being drawn up to determine the source of the money used for elections and to set a higher limit for expenditures.
The government wants the donations that individuals and companies make to politicians during elections to be made more transparent.
The draft law envisages the prevention of "decision money" used in elections.
In the draft, parties and individuals are required to spend the money they will use in their election campaigns from a bank account.
Thus all the money spent will be under the control of the Romanian Election Commission so that it will be more transparent and orderly.
Also, it is planned to set an upper limit on the expenditures in the design.
Keywords: Romania, election spending, transparency, Bucharest

Bahçeli will be resting today
It was reported that MHP Party Chairman Devlet Bahçeli would rest today in a private hospital in Çayırova District of Kocaeli following his angiography.
MHP Chairman Devlet Bahçeli had angiography at Anadolu Health Centre in Çayırova.
A written statement was made by the hospital about the health condition of Devlet Bahçeli.
In a statement, it was said, "As mentioned in the MHP press release, he was hospitalized in our hospital as part of a health check that had been planned before."
Coronary angiography was performed under controls.
The statement was given that "His health condition is very good and he is resting at our hospital today."
MHP Kocaeli MP Saffet Sancaklı, who came to the hospital to visit Devlet Bahçeli, said in a statement, "Our party leader, as you know, went through a controlled angiogram."
He is in good health.
He will continue his rest in the hospital today as well.
He gives everyone his best regards.
Our health is also very good, we don't have any problems.
Tomorrow, the doctors will take another look.
She said, "You know that in these situations the most important thing is what the doctors say."
Attacks on journalists have become routine in Turkey.
Before Prime Minister Davutoglu's visit, who is going to London next week, 25 famous writers sent a letter to the Prime Minister Cameron of England with a common signature.
PEN members asked Cameron to raise the declining freedom of press and expression at his meeting with Davutoğlu.

Leading writers from Britain have sent a letter to Prime Minister David Cameron, requesting that he bring up the issue of press and freedom of expression during Turkish counterpart Ahmet Davutoglu's upcoming visit to London next week.

Twenty-five writers, including the presidents of PEN International in the UK, Wales and Scotland, wrote a letter expressing their serious concerns about "unprecedented repression of freedom of expression" in Turkey.

The writers who point out that threats and physical attacks on journalists, authors and publishers have now become commonplace, cited the attack on the headquarters of Hürriyet Newspaper, the raid and seizure of Koza İpek Media Group as examples.

In the letter, signed by PEN members including Tom Stoppard, Ali Smith, Ian Rankin and Elif Şafak, it was emphasized that three journalists working with the Vice News were arrested, and cases were filed against other journalists, and the arrests of the journalists continued.

The reporters, who stressed that the arrest of Can Dündar and Erdem Gül in the MIT TIRs case also caused concern, stated that "It is essential to allow journalists in Turkey to fulfill their occupational duties in the society and to inform the public without restriction and censorship."
He noted that the attacks on journalists, writers and publishers are eroding the freedom of all of Turkish society.
He said that journalists and writers were subject to intimidation methods ranging from physical attacks because of the widespread "culture of impunity."

The authors point out that the number of Turkish citizens who were charged with the accusation of "insulting the president" has increased and Erdoğan filed more cases of insult after he was elected in 2014 than all his predecessors combined.
Davutoğlu's words have remained unfulfilled
It was emphasized that he is one of a few government officials who expressed support for freedom of the press and it was noted that these words failed to translate into action.
The letter carried the statement, "Therefore Davutoğlu's London visit creates an important opportunity to make a clear commitment to free expression in Turkey."
The writers asked Cameron to ensure that the government, from Prime Minister Davutoğlu, is respectful of Turkey's obligations on freedom of expression.
In the petition, 25 writers who have signed their names:

Monica Ali, Alan Bissett, William Boyd, Chris Brookmyre, Gillian Clarke, Drew Campbell (President of Scottish PEN), Fflur Dafydd, Stevie Davies, Menna Elfyn (President of Welsh PEN), Moris Farhi, Maureen Freely (President of English PEN), Richard Gwyn, Mark Haddon, David Hare, Eva Hoffman, Hari Kunzru, Robert Minhinnick, Blake Morrison, Neel Mukherjee, Ian Rankin, Elif Şafak, Owen Sheers, Ali Smith, Tom Stoppard, Sarah Waters.
Clashes in Cizre have spread to all neighborhoods and two children have been killed in the courtyard of a house.
The curfew declared in the Cizre district of Şırnak on 14 December continues.
Gunshots and explosions have not stopped since the first day of the ban.
The residents of the district, where sometimes very violent conflicts occur, leave the district.
An explosive hit a house in Dağkapı neighborhood and two children, ages 11 and 12, lost their lives.
The curfew in Cizre left behind its 33rd day.
The clashes between the security forces and the PKK have left the people in a difficult situation.

Citizens living in Nur, Cudi, Sur, and Yafes neighborhoods, where there are trenches, left the neighborhoods, where there is no electricity and water for 33 days, during the 33 days that remained behind.
The people living here also had to emigrate due to the clashes that happened in neighbourhoods where there were no trenches and barricades.
While some of the citizens left the town carrying white flags attached to their cars, others left carrying whatever they could, seeking refuge in neighboring towns.
When conflicts were underway in neighborhoods where there were trenches and barricades, the residents here had moved to more central neighborhoods.
Yet, citizens were forced to move out of these neighborhoods too because of the conflicts that have been taking place in them recently.
In Dagkapi neighborhood, the uncle and the children Yusuf Akalin, 12, and Busra Akalin, 11, lost their lives when the explosive that hit the door of the house where they were in the yard hit them.
In a district in Saha neighborhood where the population density is high, 3 people were injured after an explosive was thrown at a building.
The need for cash arose for most citizens as the withdrawal of the ban passed a month.
The citizens of the district, where all the banks and ATMs are closed, had to use their credit cards.
Citizens without a credit card are in a difficult situation.
With their needs for food and medicine unmet, many residents flee.
Those who are remaining in the district are surviving with the help of their relatives and the Cizre philanthropists.
In the district where only emergency cases can go the the hospital, no medical intervention can be given for those who have toothache.
Since the beginning of the large scale operation on 14 December, the schools have been closed and education has not been provided in the district.
The students who will take the Open Education Faculty (AÖF) exam which will be held on 16 and 17 January could not take the exam.
The Ministry of National Education announced that the exam of the students in the districts of Silopi and Cizre will take place in Mardin.

However, the students who did not want to go to the exam could not participate because there was no ban on leaving the house in the districts, there were no vehicles to go to Mardin and the entrances to the districts were banned.
There are a large number of dead and wounded.

At least 23 people were killed and 33 people were wounded in a bomb and armed attack on a popular hotel and the cafe next to it in Ouagadougou, the capital of the West African country of Burkina Faso.
126 people who were taken hostage in an operation following a gun attack were rescued.
The Minister of Security reported that three of the attackers have been neutralized.
Several armed and masked assailants staged a raid on a 147-room hotel and luxury restaurant in the capital Ouagadougou on Friday evening at around 8 p.m. local time.
Five hours after the first raid, French and UN security forces stationed in Gao state in Mali began their operation, and the first hostage rescue news came in.
President Roch Marc Christian Kabore said in a statement that at least 23 people from 18 different nations had been killed in the incident and 33 people were injured.
One hundred and twenty six people were rescued in the operation conducted after the assault.
